section.name: STRAT & COMPET ADVANTAGE: Strategy and Competitive Advantage

comments:
Management 701 focuses on the strategy issues at the business unit level through examining the question of how firms can create and sustain a competitive advantage. This class also offers students insight into the topics that include the creation of competitive advantage through commitment, competitor analysis, different organizational responses to environmental changes, real options, modularity, and increasing returns. Students in this class will have a chance to do a term-length project in which groups of students work on firm analyses that require the application of the course concepts.

Most students enjoyed this class and said that “the class greatly extends the frameworks learned in earlier strategy classes and introduces several new ones.”  Students “learned an amazing amount of information that directly prepared them for a job in strategy.” Students suggest that this class will be “useful for managers.”

Overall, Professor Siggelkow received compliments from students. Many students regarded Professor Siggelkow as “one of the best professors at Wharton.” Students also described professor Siggelkow as an “excellent speaker, passionate and articulate on the subject matter, a true expert, and a leading mind in the areas discussed.”

Students said although there was a “heavy” load of reading in terms of assigned case readings for each class, as well as the 70 page paper which also requires a 50 page draft and presentation, the readings were nonetheless “purposeful and enabled students to learn the course concepts.” Students suggested that “anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of corporate strategy should take this class.”
